title: Ultra black Futura-ish kind of font
content:
Does anyone know this font?  
It's used on electronics around 1975 (Moog synthesizers)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111704im_/http:/typophile.com/files/font-id_4829.jpg)

Font: 

 http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/ortizlopez/ol-london/ 

Solved By: 

 [donshottype](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111704/http:/typophile.com/user/205259 "View user profile.")
author: Baszz

comments.content:
Because it appears so wide I think it is Mkaputt Expanded by Manfred Klein

[http://www.dafont.com/mkaputt-expanded.font](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111704/http:/www.dafont.com/mkaputt-expanded.font "http://www.dafont.com/mkaputt-expanded.font")

The age of photo distorted fonts.  
First I cleaned up your image

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111704im_/http:/typophile.com/files/UnknownTypophile116830SM_4034.jpg)
  
Then I reduced the width to 50% -- so that the dot on the I is round not a wide oval  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111704im_/http:/typophile.com/files/UnknownTypophile116830Width@50Pct_6447.jpg)
  
Now it looks more familiar.  
Very similar to Futura Extra Bold, but the \_e\_ is different.  
Don

Other near misses available in 1975 Twentieth Century, Fute PL Book.  
Don

Now here is a font that fits the wide text exactly -- give or take some fuzziness in the image -- but was apparently designed almost three decades later

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111704im_/http:/typophile.com/files/OLLondonBlackTypophile116830_3441.jpg)
  
Dennis Ortiz-Lopez's OL London Black [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/ortizlopez/ol-london/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111704/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ortizlopez/ol-london/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/ortizlopez/ol-london/")  
Something to think about.

Wow!!! Thanks for the help Don!! :)))  
I noticed the 'e' in Futura Extra Bold that's why I posted the picture here to identify the correct font!  
You've made quite some work of it! :)  
The unstretched version really looks like Futura although I like this 'e' more then the original...

Here's another picture of a different product of that time made by Moog:  
 [http://3.bp.blogspot.com/\_rScBRKlTdoE/TAGeXU8aV1I/AAAAAAABFyw/sQME7\_mf4x...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111704/http:/3.bp.blogspot.com/_rScBRKlTdoE/TAGeXU8aV1I/AAAAAAABFyw/sQME7_mf4xU/s1600/P5280013.jpg "http://3.bp.blogspot.com/\_rScBRKlTdoE/TAGeXU8aV1I/AAAAAAABFyw/sQME7\_mf4xU/s1600/P5280013.jpg")

Here I also like the lowercase 'g' more then in the Futura Extra Bold. The 'y' seems just a bit different too.  
The rest seems to be similar when scaling the whole 50%.

The Ol London font is a nice find too!! Maybe I'll just go for that one!

Thanks Don!

![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111704im_/http:/typophile.com/files/OLLondonBlackTypophile116830B_4010.jpg)
  
I can't spot any difference between OL London and the your second image.  
I suspect that OL might have based OL London on the same photo-lettering era font as was used by Moog. This is way too close for co-incidence.  
Don

Haha, it's quite a 'co-incidence'! Or maybe Dennis Ortiz-Lopez just likes Moog synths! ;)

I think this one is solved!

Thanks again!!

Keyboardist Ray Manzarek used a Moog synthesizer on Strange Days in 1967, first major Rock and Roll recording to feature a Moog synthesizer. [http://moogfoundation.org/sonic-history-of-moog-instruments-early-record...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111704/http:/moogfoundation.org/sonic-history-of-moog-instruments-early-recordings/ "http://moogfoundation.org/sonic-history-of-moog-instruments-early-recordings/") More bands and artists that have used Moog synthesizers [http://rateyourmusic.com/list/repete86/bands\_artists\_that\_use\_have\_used\_...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111704/http:/rateyourmusic.com/list/repete86/bands_artists_that_use_have_used_moog_synthesizers/ "http://rateyourmusic.com/list/repete86/bands\_artists\_that\_use\_have\_used\_moog\_synthesizers/")  
Great stuff!  
Don
